body_text.text: However, there are few reports of MPC for gastric cancer.
This is because gastric cancer is less frequent in Western Europe and the U.S. than it is in East Asia.
In addition, multiple primary cancers of three or more sites are extremely rare conditions in patients with gastric cancer.
Therefore, there is little data which reports the incidence and clinical features of this rare disease entity.
Therefore, we performed this study to evaluate the incidence of gastric cancer patients with three or more primary cancers.
In addition, we also investigated clinicopathologic information of metachronous and synchronous gastric cancer patients in order to improve patient management and follow-up.
Between January 1995 and December 2009, 105,908 patients were diagnosed with malignancy at Severance Hospital, Yonsei University Health System.
body_text.section: M a t e r i a l s a n d M e t h o d s 1 Patients

body_text.text: Among these, 113 (0.1%) patients with MPC of three or more sites were registered, and 41 (36.3%) of these had synchronous or metachronous gastric cancer.
body_text.section: M a t e r i a l s a n d M e t h o d s 1 Patients

body_text.text: Diagnosis of gastric cancer and other MPC were pathologically confirmed in all patients.
body_text.section: M a t e r i a l s a n d M e t h o d s 1 Patients

body_text.text: We retrospectively reviewed clinicopathologic features of these 41 patients with metachronous or synchronous gastric cancer in MPC of three or more sites.
body_text.section: Methods

body_text.text: The following data was collected; gender, age at initial cancer diagnosis, stage, gastric cancer histology, and survival from the time of first diagnosis of cancer.
body_text.section: Methods

body_text.text: The tumor stage of the gastric cancer was determined according to Tumor-Node-Metastasis (TNM) classification (American Joint Committee on Cancer, 6th edition).
body_text.section: Methods

body_text.text: Two main categories were used for histological typing: differentiated type (including papillary adenocarcinoma and well and moderately differentiated tubular adenocarcinoma) and undifferentiated type (including poorly differentiated tubular adenocarcinoma, mucinous adenocarcinoma, and signet ring cell adenocarcinoma).
body_text.section: Methods

body_text.text: The MPC was defined according to Warren and Gates's criteria (11).
body_text.section: Methods

body_text.text: The definition of MPC was as follows:
body_text.section: Methods

body_text.text: 1) the tumor had to have definite features of malignancy,
body_text.section: Methods

body_text.text: 2) the tumor had to be separate and distinct from the index tumor, which was gastric adenocarcinoma in this study,
body_text.section: Methods

body_text.text: 3) the possibility of the tumor being a metastasis of the index tumor had to be ruled out.
body_text.section: Methods

body_text.text: Based on this definition, we selected a total of 113 patients with three or more primary cancers between 1995 and 2009.
body_text.section: Methods

body_text.text: Then, we selected 41 patients who were diagnosed with primary gastric cancer, synchronously or metachronously.
body_text.section: Methods

body_text.text: In terms of the chronicity, we defined synchronous and metachronous cancer based on Moertel's definition.
body_text.section: Methods

body_text.text: Synchronous cancers were defined as those occurring within 6 months of the first primary cancer, while metachronous cancers were defined as those occurring more than 6 months later (12).
body_text.section: Methods

body_text.text: Overall survival was defined as the time from first primary cancer diagnosis to death (of any cause).
body_text.section: Methods

body_text.text: For statistical analysis, we used the χ 2 -test and Fisher's exact test for categorical variables and the student's t-test for continuous variables.
body_text.section: Statistics

body_text.text: The survival curve was calculated using the Kaplan-Meier method and the statistical difference in prognosis was analyzed using a log rank test.
body_text.section: Statistics

body_text.text: SPSS ver. 17.0 (SPSS Inc., Chicago, IL) was used throughout and p-values of ＜0.05 were considered significant.
body_text.section: Statistics

body_text.text: A total of 41 gastric cancer patients were diagnosed with three or more primary sites (GC-MPC).
body_text.section: R e s u l t s 1 Clinicopathologic features of synchronous and metachronous MPC

body_text.text: Among these, 34 (82.9%) had triple, 6 (14.6%) had quadruple and 1 (2.4%) had quintuple primary malignancies.
body_text.section: R e s u l t s 1 Clinicopathologic features of synchronous and metachronous MPC

body_text.text: Seventeen patients (41.5%) were diagnosed with MPC synchronously, whereas 24 (58.5%) were diagnosed metachronously.
body_text.section: R e s u l t s 1 Clinicopathologic features of synchronous and metachronous MPC

body_text.text: Among 17 patients with synchronous GC-MPC, 6 patients were diagnosed with other malignancies before gastric cancer.
body_text.section: R e s u l t s 1 Clinicopathologic features of synchronous and metachronous MPC

body_text.text: In addition, 8 of 17 patients had 1 simultaneous malignancy in addition to gastric cancer, and 8 other patients had 2.
body_text.section: R e s u l t s 1 Clinicopathologic features of synchronous and metachronous MPC

body_text.text: Furthermore, one patient was diagnosed simultaneously with 3 other malignancies (esophagus, rectum, small bowel).
body_text.section: R e s u l t s 1 Clinicopathologic features of synchronous and metachronous MPC

body_text.text: Meanwhile, of 24 patients diagnosed with metachronous GC-MPC, 13 patients developed other malignancies after gastric cancer and 11 had other malignancies before gastric cancer.
body_text.section: R e s u l t s 1 Clinicopathologic features of synchronous and metachronous MPC

body_text.text: Clinicopathologic data for synchronous and metachronous GC-MPC patients are described in Table 1.
body_text.section: R e s u l t s 1 Clinicopathologic features of synchronous and metachronous MPC

body_text.text: Twenty-nine (70.7%) patients were male, and the median age was 59 years (range, 27 to 79 years).
body_text.section: R e s u l t s 1 Clinicopathologic features of synchronous and metachronous MPC

body_text.text: The median time interval between the first cancer and the second cancer was 42 months (range, 11.5 to 225.2 months) and the time interval between the second and third cancer was 43 months (range, 7.7 to 133.3 months).
body_text.section: R e s u l t s 1 Clinicopathologic features of synchronous and metachronous MPC

body_text.text: Of the 39 evaluable patients, the TNM stage of the gastric cancer was early stage (I or II) in 34 cases (82.9%) and advanced stage (III or IV) in 5 cases (12.2%).
body_text.section: R e s u l t s 1 Clinicopathologic features of synchronous and metachronous MPC

body_text.text: Regarding stage, histology, and time interval between each cancer, there were no differences between the synchronous and metachronous groups.
body_text.section: R e s u l t s 1 Clinicopathologic features of synchronous and metachronous MPC

body_text.text: Patients in the metachronous group had more female (p=0.003) and younger (p=0.013) patients than those in synchronous group.
body_text.section: R e s u l t s 1 Clinicopathologic features of synchronous and metachronous MPC

body_text.text: The incidence of early-stage and poorlydifferentiated tumor was slightly higher in gastric cancer patients with metachronous GC-MPC than in those with synchronous GC-MPC (91.7% vs. 70.6% for stage I/II and 54.2% vs. 23.5% for poorly differentiated histology, respectively).
body_text.section: R e s u l t s 1 Clinicopathologic features of synchronous and metachronous MPC

body_text.text: Excluding gastric cancer, we also analyzed the stages of the other primary cancers.
body_text.section: R e s u l t s 1 Clinicopathologic features of synchronous and metachronous MPC

body_text.text: In the subset analysis, early stage cancers were slightly more frequent in the synchronous group (25% vs. 42.3%) without statistical significance (p=0.217).
body_text.section: R e s u l t s 1 Clinicopathologic features of synchronous and metachronous MPC

body_text.text: For a total of 41 patients, the most common site of MPC other than gastric cancer was colorectal cancer (n=16, 39%), followed by cancers in the lung (n=10, 24.4%), head & neck (n=10, 24.4%), and thyroid (n=9, 22%), as shown in Table 2 and Fig. 1A.
body_text.section: Site distribution of MPC

body_text.text: We also analyzed site distribution of MPC according to the chronicity.
body_text.section: Site distribution of MPC

body_text.text: Among the 17 synchronous gastric cancer patients, other common primary sites were as follows ( Fig. 1B): head & neck (n=8, 47.1%), esophagus (n=6, 35.3%) and lung (n=4, 23.5%).
body_text.section: Site distribution of MPC

body_text.text: In contrast, the most common sites for the 24 metachronous patients were: colorectum (n=14, 58.3%), thyroid (n=7, 29.2%) and lung (n=6, 25%).
body_text.section: Site distribution of MPC

body_text.text: By way of comparison, esophageal cancer and head & neck cancer were demonstrated more frequently in the synchronous group (35.3% vs. 4.2%, p≤0.001 and 47.1% vs. 8.3%, p=0.008, respectively) while colorectal cancer was more frequent in the metachronous group (58.3% vs. 11.8%, p=0.003).
body_text.section: Site distribution of MPC

body_text.text: We also analyzed the site distribution of MPC in terms of gender distribution.
body_text.section: Site distribution of MPC

body_text.text: Among 41 GC-MPC patients, 29 (70.7%) patients were male and 12 (29.3%) were female.
body_text.section: Site distribution of MPC

body_text.text: In males, the most common site for MPC was the head & neck (n=10, 34.5%), followed by the colorectum (n=9, 31%), lung (n=7, 24.1%), kidney (n=7, 24.1%), and esophagus (n=6, 20.7%) as shown in Fig. 2A.
body_text.section: Site distribution of MPC

body_text.text: In females, the most common site was the colorectum (n=7, 58.3%), followed by the thyroid (n=4, 33.3%), breast (n=4, 33.3%), and endometrium (n=3, 25%).

body_text.text: When categorizing primary cancer sites based on smoking correlation, male patients demonstrated more frequent smoking related cancers such as head & neck, lung, kidney, esophagus, bladder cancers than female patients (n=34, 53.1% vs. n=4, 15.4%, respectively, p=0.002).

body_text.text: Fig. 2B and 2C compare the patients with synchronous primary cancer and those with metachronous primary cancer with regard to gender.

body_text.text: With a median follow-up duration for the whole group (41 patients) of 5.6 years (range, 0.1 to 23.2 years), the median overall survival duration and 10-year overall survival rate were 14.8 years (figure not shown) and 63.2%, respectively.
body_text.section: Survival outcome and cause of death

body_text.text: The same figures for the synchronous and metachronous GC-MPC groups, respectively, were 4.7 years and 48.2%, and 14.8 years and 80.7% (p＜0.001) (Fig. 3).
body_text.section: Survival outcome and cause of death

body_text.text: We analyzed overall survival by gender, stage distribution, and gastric cancer histology.
body_text.section: Survival outcome and cause of death

body_text.text: The survival differences between the synchronous and metachronous GC-MPC groups were significant in male (p=0.002), stage I/II (p=0.011) and well differentiated histology (p=0.01) groups, while the difference in female (p=0.629), stage III/IV (p=0.502) and poorly differentiated histology (p=0.154) groups did not reach statistical significance (Table 3).
body_text.section: Survival outcome and cause of death

body_text.text: At the time of the analysis, 13 patients had died of either gastric or other primary cancers.
body_text.section: Survival outcome and cause of death

body_text.text: Of these 13 patients, 8 patients were metachronous and 5 patients were synchronous.
body_text.section: Survival outcome and cause of death

body_text.text: The causes of death are presented in Table 4.
body_text.section: Survival outcome and cause of death

body_text.text: We described the clinicopathologic features of a rare disease entity, GC-MPC, and analyzed its clinical significances to establish follow-up plan in cancer patients.
body_text.section: D i s c u s s i o n

body_text.text: During the 15 year investigation period, 0.1% of cancer patients had a MPC with three or more primary sites, and 36.3% of these were gastric cancer patients.
body_text.section: D i s c u s s i o n

body_text.text: This incidence is consistent with previous studies which reported prevalences of 0.029 to 1.7% (7,13,14).
body_text.section: D i s c u s s i o n

body_text.text: Synchronous and metachronous gastric cancer patients showed somewhat different second cancer distribution.
body_text.section: D i s c u s s i o n

body_text.text: For metachronous gastric cancer patients, the most common cancer sites in descending order were: colorectum, thyroid, lung, kidney and breast.
body_text.section: D i s c u s s i o n

body_text.text: This finding is similar to the distribution of cancer in the general Korean population (15): stomach, colorectum, thyroid, breast, liver and lung in descending order of frequency.
body_text.section: D i s c u s s i o n

body_text.text: However, interestingly, the site distribution for synchronous gastric cancer demonstrated a different order: head & neck, esophagus, lung, and kidney.
body_text.section: D i s c u s s i o n

body_text.text: A possible reason for this phenomenon may be shared risk factors, especially cigarette smoking.
body_text.section: D i s c u s s i o n

body_text.text: Smoking is thought to be a risk factor for gastric cancer (16,17).
body_text.section: D i s c u s s i o n

body_text.text: The gender difference between synchronous and metachronous gastric cancer also supports this assumption.
body_text.section: D i s c u s s i o n

body_text.text: More male gastric cancer patients were diagnosed initially with multiple synchronous sites than female patients.
body_text.section: D i s c u s s i o n

body_text.text: In further subgroup analysis, smoking related cancers (head & neck, lung, esophagus, kidney, bladder) were significantly more common in males than in female patients.
body_text.section: D i s c u s s i o n

body_text.text: This suggests that smoking plays an important role in the increased incidence of synchronous disease in male patients.
body_text.section: D i s c u s s i o n

body_text.text: More careful examination of these sites may therefore be needed at the time of diagnosis and during the followup period of the gastric cancer.
body_text.section: D i s c u s s i o n

body_text.text: Further epidemiologic study is warranted to clarify this point.
body_text.section: D i s c u s s i o n

body_text.text: In addition, the metachronous gastric cancer group contained more female and younger cases.
body_text.section: D i s c u s s i o n

body_text.text: These findings seem to be caused by different peak ages between males and females.
body_text.section: D i s c u s s i o n

body_text.text: According to the Korean cancer registry (15), there are two peak incidences in females.
body_text.section: D i s c u s s i o n

body_text.text: Breast and thyroid cancers in females were most frequently diagnosed in the fourth and fifth decades, whereas other malignancies like gastric cancer were often found in the seventh decade.
body_text.section: D i s c u s s i o n

body_text.text: Conversely, most cancers in males were diagnosed in the seventh decade.
body_text.section: D i s c u s s i o n

body_text.text: Therefore, females were at greater risk of being diagnosed with a first primary cancer of breast or thyroid cancer at a younger age, and those who survived their first primary cancer were at greater risk of developing a metachronous second primary cancer thereafter.
body_text.section: D i s c u s s i o n

body_text.text: Although there is still little data for the underlying mechanism, three main explanations have been put forward for MPC.
body_text.section: D i s c u s s i o n

body_text.text: First, with longer survival, there is a greater likelihood of attack by many carcinogens, resulting in the development of more precancerous lesions.
body_text.section: D i s c u s s i o n

body_text.text: Additionally, assuming the risk of cancer is constant, it is more likely that precancerous lesions will develop into clinically significant cancers due to accumulation of genetic changes (6).
body_text.section: D i s c u s s i o n

body_text.text: This mechanism is explained by multistep carcinogenesis over time and the molecular and environmental changes of body associated with the aging process.
body_text.section: D i s c u s s i o n

body_text.text: Second, "field carcinogenesis" may be another mechanism for MPC Metachronous MPC group 10-year survival rate: 80.7%

body_text.section: D i s c u s s i o n

body_text.text: pathogenesis (12,18,19).
body_text.section: D i s c u s s i o n

body_text.text: This theory implies that if cells in a similar microenvironment or with similarly susceptible cell biology are exposed to the same dose of carcinogens for the same duration of time, they have a similar risk of developing into cancer (20).
body_text.section: D i s c u s s i o n

body_text.text: The association of upper aerodigestive tract cancer and lung cancer is a well studied example of the field carcinogenesis theory (21,22).
body_text.section: D i s c u s s i o n

body_text.text: Lastly, genetic vulnerability due to specific genetic mutations may be responsible.
body_text.section: D i s c u s s i o n

body_text.text: MLH1, MSH2, MSH6, PMS1, and PMS2 mutations in hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer have been known to increase the genetic susceptibility for uterus, ovary, and stomach cancer (23).
body_text.section: D i s c u s s i o n

body_text.text: The survival outcome in our study is consistent with previous studies (24,25), which suggests that metachronous patients have better prognoses than synchronous patients.
body_text.section: D i s c u s s i o n

body_text.text: In this study, the proportion of early stage (I or II) gastric cancer was 82.9%.
body_text.section: D i s c u s s i o n

body_text.text: Although recent developments in diagnosis and the introduction of mass screening programs have allowed increased detection of early gastric cancer, the proportion of early gastric cancer in this study is much higher than in the general population of Korea (50%).
body_text.section: D i s c u s s i o n

body_text.text: As patients with histories of cancer tend to undergo regular medical check-ups, this could lead to earlier diagnoses of new malignancies at curable stages (6).
body_text.section: D i s c u s s i o n

body_text.text: For these reasons, multiplicity of primary malignancies does not always imply a poor prognosis.
body_text.section: D i s c u s s i o n

body_text.text: Furthermore, metachronous status may sometimes result in a better survival outcome due to the detection of second or third primary cancer at earlier stages.
body_text.section: D i s c u s s i o n

body_text.text: Also, the better survival in the metachronous GC-MPC was maintained even when we did not include the favorable prognostic cancers such as thyroid or prostate cancer (data not shown).
body_text.section: D i s c u s s i o n

body_text.text: Although our study had some unique findings, there were two potential limitations.
body_text.section: D i s c u s s i o n

body_text.text: First, the retrospective single center nature of our study may limit the generalization of our results.
body_text.section: D i s c u s s i o n

body_text.text: However, our analysis is based on data from the registry of the Yonsei Cancer Center, a major, 2000-bed tertiary hospital in Korea.
body_text.section: D i s c u s s i o n

body_text.text: This well organized and standardized tumor registry has records for every case of carcinoma in situ or carcinoma in our hospital since 1980.
body_text.section: D i s c u s s i o n

body_text.text: Therefore, the data from our registry can be interpreted as being broadly representative of Korea as a whole.
body_text.section: D i s c u s s i o n

body_text.text: Secondly, because of the long followup duration, some information was insufficient, and altered diagnostic and treatment strategies may have influenced the results.
body_text.section: D i s c u s s i o n

body_text.text: Therefore, further validation with nationwide data is needed, and this information might be useful in the establishment of a national diagnostic/treatment strategy for gastric cancer patients.
body_text.section: D i s c u s s i o n

body_text.text: We reported the clinical features of multiple primary cancer in gastric cancer patients.
body_text.section: C o n c l u s i o n

body_text.text: To our knowledge, this is the first study describing the clinical features and prognosis of three or more primary sites in gastric cancer.
body_text.section: C o n c l u s i o n

body_text.text: The early detection of additional primary malignancies will enable prompt management with curative intent.
body_text.section: C o n c l u s i o n

body_text.text: Therefore, based on our results, further genetic and epidemiologic studies are warranted to clarify understanding of the pathogenesis and improve therapeutic outcome.
